title: actfts
text: actfts package consolidates various R time series functions related econometric financial analysis, integrating tools single package. Educators researchers can understand time series analysis without burden fragmented code spread across multiple resources, creating coherent efficient results reading. actfts package simplifies manages scattered code educational environment, allowing students focus data analysis result interpretation. Moreover, gain deeper practical understanding concepts without overwhelmed navigating multiple tools syntaxes.

title: actfts
text: actfts package provides three time series datasets automatically updated FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data) database United States. datasets designed help practice using package’s functions. brief overview : Gross Domestic Product, measure quantifies total monetary value goods services produced within country specific period, typically quarter year. provides comprehensive overview nation’s economic activity, reflecting size economic health. Economists often use GDP compare economic performance across countries regions assess impact economic policies. practical code example retrieve GDP data. Personal Consumption Expenditures represents total value goods services consumed households nonprofit institutions serving households within economy. critical component GDP, PCE reveals consumer behavior spending patterns. covers expenditures durable goods, non durable goods, services, providing insights consumer confidence living standards. handy code allows retrieve PCE data Disposable Personal Income refers amount money households available spending saving deducting taxes mandatory charges. indicator consumer purchasing power financial health. DPI significantly impacts consumer spending saving behaviors, affecting overall economic growth. Analysts frequently study DPI identify trends personal savings rates consumption patterns. practical code snippet obtaining DPI data.

title: actfts
text: beginning examples, define concepts acfinter() function used calculate essentials.

title: actfts
text: ACF measures correlation time series lags different intervals. helps identify patterns temporal dependence (Box & Jenkins, 1976).

title: actfts
text: PACF measures correlation time series lags, removing influence intermediate lags. essential determine appropriate order AR(p) model (Box & Jenkins, 1976).

title: actfts
text: Ljung-Box Test statistically evaluates whether autocorrelations time series differ zero. Analysts commonly use check independence residuals ARIMA models (Ljung & Box, 1978)

title: actfts
text: Similar Ljung-Box test, Box-Pierce Test statistical test evaluates independence residuals time series model. simpler less refined version compared Ljung-Box test (Box & Pierce, 1970)

title: actfts
text: KPSS Test (Kwiatkowski-Phillips-Schmidt-Shin) statistical test checks stationarity time series, mainly whether series stationary around mean deterministic trend (Kwiatkowski et al., 1992)

title: actfts
text: Box-Cox Transformation data transformation technique applies power function stabilize variance make time series closely resemble normal distribution (Box & Cos, 1964)

title: actfts
text: Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test nonparametric test compares sample distribution reference probability distribution compares two sample distributions assess whether differ significantly (Kolmogorov, 1933) (Smirnov, 1948)

title: actfts
text: Shapiro-Wilk Test statistical test evaluates normality data set. particularly effective small sample sizes assesses whether sample comes normally distributed population (Shapiro & Wilk, 1965)

title: actfts
text: first example, analyze United States GDP time series. use acfinter() function see ACF, PACF, Box_Pierce, Pv_Box, Ljung_Box, Pv_Ljung. can also see normality analysis stationarity analysis. Finally, plot ACF, PACF, Pv LJUNG BOX. Therefore, use following code analyze first ten lags explain result acfinter() function. outcome variable encompasses three primary tests: ACF-PACF, Stationarity, Normality. ACF-PACF component shows multiple lags significant correlations tested Box-Pierce Ljung-Box tests. Regarding stationarity tests, function acfinter() provides ADF, KPSS-Level, KPSS-Trend, PP results. test nuances, common aim determine series stationary. ADF PP tests yield p-values 0.99. Since values exceed significance level 0.95, reject null hypothesis stationarity, confirming presence unit root trend component GDP time series. contrast, KPSS-Level KPSS-Trend tests return p-values 0.01, indicating rejection null hypothesis cases. tests show non-stationary time series level trend. third component, Shapiro-Wilk Kolmogorov-Smirnov normality tests used conclude non-normal distribution time series. results lead us reject null hypothesis normality. Finally, Box-Cox transformation test determine transformation needed stabilize time series variance. Based test results, transformations : 1: transformation. 0: Natural logarithm. 0.5: Square root. 2: Square. -1: Inverse. results tests near 0, tests show apply natural logarithm transformation.

what: Example two: use the confidence interval
title: actfts
text: output function acfinter() discussed. following examples explore utilize argument function provide important considerations proper application. argument ci.method allows selection constant confidence intervals (“white”) dynamic confidence intervals (“ma”). ci argument specifies desired value 0 0.99. utilizing arguments, one set ci.method argument “ma” ci argument confidence interval 0.98. Thus, following code can used: illustrated, function acfinter() arguments ci.method ci adjusts results according specified confidence interval. Additionally, can observed confidence intervals plot constant display dynamic behavior.

title: actfts
text: Continuing GDP analysis, “delta” argument can employed examine first three differences time series. analysis focus first difference, following code utilized. setting argument “delta” “diff1”, function acfinter() display first difference time series. Firstly, ACF-PACF test indicates significant autocorrelation 10th lag. Box-Pierce Ljung-Box tests confirm finding supported plot. stationarity tests confirm first difference stationarity GDP time series; null hypothesis rejected. However, KPSS test results, level trend, suggest first difference GDP time series stationary. Conversely, normality test indicates first difference GDP time series normally distributed, null hypothesis rejected tests. noted Box-Cox test variance stabilization applies level time series differences.

title: actfts
text: Finally, function acfinter() lets users view results interactively. interactive argument used, acftable specified. Additionally, dynamic visualization results possible. Moreover, results time series analysis can downloaded setting download argument TRUE, generating Excel file containing numerical results PNG image resolution 300 dpi, includes ACF, PACF, Ljung-Box Pv graphs. files saved user’s Documents folder. example code use:
code: result <- acfinter(GDP_data, lag = 10, interactive = "acftable", download = TRUE)

title: actfts
text: can analyze time series xts, ts, integer, vector (numeric) formats. , use different format, acfinter() function won’t work. case, must convert data format initially showed . Finally, packages acfinter() uses operation : xts (Ryan & Ulrich, 2020), tseries (Trapletti & Hornik, 2020), reactable (Glaz, 2023), openxlsx (Walker, 2023), plotly (Sievert, 2020), forecast (Hyndman & Khandakar, 2008) stats (R Core Team, 2023).

what: Autocorrelation Tools Featured for Time Series
title: Autocorrelation Tools Featured for Time Series
text: actfts package offers flexible approach time series analysis focusing Autocorrelation (ACF), Partial Autocorrelation (PACF), stationarity tests, generating interactive plots dynamic data visualization. processes input data validating transforming according specified differences. calculates ACF PACF several lags performs Box-Pierce, Ljung-Box, ADF, KPSS, PP tests. function organizes results tables, options save TIFF files Excel spreadsheets, interactive mode provides -screen visualization ACF-PACF stationarity test outcomes.

what: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
title: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
text: acfinter computes visualizes ACF PACF given time series, performs stationarity tests, optionally generates interactive tables plots.

title: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
code: acfinter(   datag,   lag = 72,   ci.method = "white",   ci = 0.95,   interactive = NULL,   delta = "levels",   download = FALSE )

title: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
text: datag numeric vector time series object. lag Maximum number lags ACF PACF. Default 72. ci.method Method confidence intervals: "white" (default) "ma". ci Confidence level confidence intervals. Default 0.95. interactive Character string specifying whether create interactive table: "acftable" ACF-PACF table, "stattable" stationarity tests table. Default NULL. delta Transformation data: "levels" (default), "diff1", "diff2", "diff3". download Logical indicating whether save results files. Default FALSE.

title: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
text: list two elements: "ACF-PACF Test" "Stationary Test". function also creates interactive plots tables specified.

title: ACF and PACF Analysis with Interactive Features — acfinter
code: data <- actfts::GDPEEUU result <- actfts::acfinter(data, lag = 20, ci.method = "white", interactive = "acftable") print(result) #> NULL

what: actfts: Autocorrelation Tools Featured for Time Series — actfts-package
title: actfts: Autocorrelation Tools Featured for Time Series — actfts-package
text: 'actfts' package provides tools performing autocorrelation analysis time series data. includes functions compute visualize autocorrelation function (ACF) partial autocorrelation function (PACF). Additionally, performs Dickey-Fuller, KPSS, Phillips-Perron unit root tests assess stationarity time series. Theoretical foundations based Box Cox (1964) doi:10.1111/j.2517-6161.1964.tb00553.x , Box Jenkins (1976) <isbn:978-0-8162-1234-2>, Box Pierce (1970) doi:10.1080/01621459.1970.10481180 . Statistical methods also drawn Kolmogorov (1933) doi:10.1007/BF00993594 , Kwiatkowski et al. (1992) doi:10.1016/0304-4076(92)90104-Y , Ljung Box (1978) doi:10.1093/biomet/65.2.297 . package integrates functions 'forecast' (Hyndman & Khandakar, 2008) https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=forecast, 'tseries' (Trapletti & Hornik, 2020) https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tseries, 'xts' (Ryan & Ulrich, 2020) https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=xts, 'stats' (R Core Team, 2023) https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/00Index.html. Additionally, provides visualization tools via 'plotly' (Sievert, 2020) https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=plotly 'reactable' (Glaz, 2023) https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=reactable. package also incorporates macroeconomic datasets U.S. Bureau Economic Analysis: Disposable Personal Income (DPI) https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DPI, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/GDP, Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCEC) https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PCEC.
